Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research/IDBR: High-Throughput Measurement of Oxygen Consumption Rates of Single Cells Using Wide-Field Optical-Resolution Photoacoustic Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research/IDBR: High-Throughput Measurement of Oxygen Consumption Rates of Single Cells Using Wide-Field Optical-Resolution Photoacoustic Microscopy
An award is made to the Washington University in St. Louis to develop a novel wide-field opticalresolution photoacoustic microscope (OR-PAM) and a new high-density single-cell array substrate to achieve simultaneous and high-throughput measurements of single-cell oxygen consumption rates (OCRs) for a large population of cells. OCR is a critical parameter of the functioning of the cells, which is directly linked to their metabolic state. So far, OCR measurements have been performed on bulk populations of cells. Recent studies have shown increasing evidence of cell-to-cell heterogeneity among previously assumed homogeneous populations. Measuring the average response of a cell population to a stimulus may not well reflect individual cell responses. Therefore, conducting OCR measurements on single cells will provide more accurate information on cellular functioning, not only for individual cells but also for the entire cell population. OR-PAM is capable of "label-free" detection of a wide range of biochemicals with high sensitivity and spatial resolution. Combining wide-field OR-PAM with high-density single-cell array substrates will enable high-throughput screening of a large population of single cells in a timely manner for the first time.
This project will lay a solid technical foundation for developing a new class of scientific instruments to study heterogeneity in cellular metabolism. These instruments will be accurate, high-resolution, highthroughput, easy-to-use, and low-cost. Therefore, they will significantly impact many areas of biological research. The multidisciplinary nature of this research is expected to offer learning and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to cross their discipline boundaries by learning new principles and methods. Grade 7-12 teachers and students from underrepresented school districts will be involved. Research results will be incorporated into the PIs' course development at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. They will be also disseminated through paper publications and outreach activities to the research community and general public. In addition to the outreach plans, a comprehensive dissemination plan has also been developed. The developed methods, devices and system will be actively promoted to the biological research community through conference presentations, invited talks and seminars. Collaborations and partnerships with bioinstrumentation industries will be established to explore potential opportunities for further development and commercialization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) project is to develop an instrument capable of simultaneous and high-throughput measurement of single-cell oxygen consumption rates (OCRs) for a large population of cells. To achieve this goal, we have developed a label-free high-throughput single-cell OCR measurement system. Using this newly developed system, we have accomplished simultaneous measurements of single-cell OCRs for thousands of cells, two orders of magnitude more than the current state-of-the-art single-cell OCR measurement techniques. This single-cell OCR measurement system combines a high-speed wide-field functional photoacoustic microscopy (fPAM) system developed by our group at Washington University in St. Louis and a high-density single-cell microwell array developed by our collaborators at Texas A&M University. The high-speed wide-field fPAM system can accurately measure the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, the intrinsic oxygen carrier in blood, with high sensitivity and spatial resolution. The high-density single-cell microwell array can create sealed and separated microenvironments for thousands of single cells of interest mixed with blood. By monitoring the oxygen depletion from hemoglobin in each sealed microwell, the system utilizes hemoglobin as both an oxygen supplier and sensor, and measures the OCRs of thousands of single cells simultaneously. We have demonstrated the capability of the newly developed system by measuring the single-cell OCRs of normal and cancer cell lines. 

The key parameter measured by the newly developed instrument, OCR, is an important indicator of the metabolic states of cells. Quantifying the single-cell OCRs for a large population of cells is valuable for understanding cellular metabolic heterogeneity, a long-standing and critical issue in cancer therapy. Previously, for a large population of cells, only the average OCR of all the cells could be measured, providing no information at the single cell level or on cellular heterogeneity. Although electrical and fluorescent oxygen sensor based methods have measured single-cell OCRs for a few tens of cells, these techniques are not suitable for high-throughput single-cell OCR measurement, because they require delicate oxygen sensors. Using our newly developed high-throughput single-cell OCR measurement system, statistically sound data on the single-cell OCRs were obtained for the first time. The system can be used as a platform to perform high-throughput single-cell OCR measurements for various cancer cell lines. The obtained knowledge of cellular metabolic heterogeneity will contribute to both fundamental cancer research and clinical cancer therapy.

In addition to label-free high-throughput single-cell OCR measurement, the high-speed wide-field fPAM system developed in this IDBR project has greatly broadened the applications of photoacoustic imaging. With its functional imaging capability and the high spatio-temporal resolution, the fPAM system has been applied to study many complex biological activities, such as neurovascular coupling, epilepsy propagation, and circulating tumor cell detection. The results obtained in this project have been actively publicized through peer-reviewed journal articles, book chapters, and conference presentations. They are also being used as materials for classroom teaching and outreach activities by the Principal Investigators. The project also provided the involved graduate, undergraduate, and high school students with valuable experiences in scientific research and improved their abilities in critical thinking, scientific writing, and teamworking.
